description: Hyperlinks to URI accessible documents
Abbreviation or acronym
Contact information
Defines a clickable area in an image map. Used only within a <map> element
Self-contained composition in a document, page, application, or site
Portion of the page that is tangentially related to the main content. Typically presented as a sidebar
Embeds audio into document

Represents text that should be stylistically offset from normal text without conveying extra importance. While historically used for bold text, it has legitimate semantic uses like keywords, product names, or other text that should be stylistically different. When emphasis or importance is needed, use <strong> instead
Base url to use for all relative urls in the document. Only one per document. Mostly used in template files to reduce boilerplate
Used to isolate a part of text that might be formatted in a different direction from other text outside it
Used to override the current text direction

Quotation. URL for the source of the quotation may be given with the cite attribute (usually not rendered, but can be used by search engines), while the text representation of the source can be given using the <cite> element
The content of an HTML document. One per document
Significant line break
Defines a button that can be clicked to submit a form or perform an action
For canvas drawing using canvas scripting API or the WebGL API
Table caption. Usually rendered below the table
Represents a reference to a creative work (citation). Mostly semantic usage but is also usually rendered as italic text
Represents a fragment of computer code. Rendered as monospace font, like <pre> but inline
Defines one or more columns in a column group. Only valid within a <colgroup>
Defines a group of columns within a table
Links a given piece of content with a machine-readable form of the content. Used where two versions of the content are available, one for humans and one for machines
Defines a list of pre-defined <option>s that represent the permissable or recommended options available to choose from within other controls (e.g. <input>)
Description definition. Each <dd> element can have multiple relevant <dt> elements (think of synonyms)
Represents that the content has been deleted. Usually rendered with a line through it and a red-ish background colour

Represents a disclosure widget from which the user can obtain additional information or controls. Usually rendered as a button or link that expands or collapses the details element. A summary must be provided using the <summary> element
Used to define a term (mostly semantic)
Represents a dialog box or window. Usually rendered as a modal or popup window
Generic container for flow content
Description list. Glossary, dictionary, or similar data in key-value 'format'. Items (dt, dd pairs) might be grouped in a <div> element
Description term. Each <dt> element can have multiple relevant <dd> elements (think a word with multiple meanings)
Emphasis. Typically rendered using an italic font style. Since both <i> and <em> are rendered the same way, they are often confused with each other; these days you'll mostly see <em> used
Same as object; if you need to embed something use object
Used to group related form elements (like radio buttons or checkboxes)
Caption for a figure. Think of image caption
Figure with optional caption. Figure is a self-contained illustration, diagram, photo, code snippet, etc. i.e. self-contained unit of content
Footer content: author's info, copyright, contact info, etc.
Defines a document section that contains interactive controls for submitting information to a server
Heading level 1 (most important)
Heading level 2
Heading level 3
Heading level 4
Heading level 5
Heading level 6 (least important)
Contains the metadata of the document: links, title, scripts, stuff like that
Introductory content. Typically a group of introductory or navigational aids. It usually might contain nav, search, etc.
Heading grouped with any secondary content, such as subheadings, alt title or a tagline
Horizontal rule. Thematic break
The root; top-level element. Also referred to as the root element

Historically presented as italic text, but this element is used to mark text that is set off from the normal text for some reason (alternative voice or mood, taxonomic designation, foreign idiomatic terms or expressions, technical terms, transliterations, thoughts, etc.)
Nested browsing context - embedding another HTML document into the current one
Embeds image into document
Defines an input field where users can enter data. A wide variety of input types are available, including text, email, password, radio buttons, checkboxes, etc.
Represents that the content has been inserted. Usually rendered with a green-ish background colour
Used to differentiate keyboard input from other text (e.g. <kbd>Ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>C</kbd>)
Caption for an item in a user interface (or in a form in this context)
Caption for the content of its parent <fieldset> element
List item. Rendered differently depending on the parent element (<menu>, <ol>, <ul>)
Specify relationships between the current document and an external resource. Used for linking css files, site icons, fonts, etc.
Main content of the document
Used to define an image map. Image maps allows geometric areas of an image to be associated with hyperlinks
Represents marked or highlighted text
Required toplevel element in MathML
Semantic alternative to <ul> but treated the same by browsers
Metadata that cannot be represented by other meta-related elements (base, link, script, style or title)

Represents a scalar measurement within a known range. Differs from <progress> in that it represents a gauge rather than a progress indicator. <progress> is for completion of a task, while <meter> is for gauges and meters
Section of a page whose purpose is to provide navigation links. Menus, ToC, indexes, etc.
Fallback content for users without JavaScript enabled (usually a notice that JavaScript is required). If js is enabled, it will not be rendered at all
External resource. is better for images,
Ordered list of items. Typically rendered as numbered list
Creates a group of options within a <select> element
Represents an option in a <select>, <optgroup> or <datalist> element
Container element into which website can inject the results of some user action
Paragraph of text
Contains zero or more elements and one element. It will first try to load the best match from the elements, falling back to the element if none match
Preformatted text. Typically rendered using a monospaced font. Whitespace is preserved
Represents the indicator of a completion of a task, typically displayed as a progress bar
Inline quotation
Used to provide fallback content for browsers that do not support ruby annotations
Specifies the ruby text component of a ruby annotation. Must be contained within a <ruby> element
Used to annotate characters with ruby text (e.g. pronunciation guides)
Strikethrough. Represents text that is no longer accurate or relevant
Sample output from a computer program. Typically rendered in monospace font
For embedding JavaScript code (but also webgl's glsl shared code and json)
Form controls for searching or filtering operation
Generic standalone section of a document. Should always have a heading with very few exceptions
Defines a dropdown list where users can select an option
For defining a slot for content to be inserted into a web component
Represents a small print text (think legal text, copyright notice, etc.)

Specifies the media resource for the <picture>, <video>, <audio> elements. Used to offer the same content in multiple formats in order to provide compatibility with different browsers and devices. Void element
Generic inline container for phrasing content, which does not inherently represent anything. Like div, but div is block-level element, while span is inline element
Strong emphasis. Typically rendered using a bold font weight
Style information (inline css basically)
Subscript
Represents a summary, caption, or legend for a <details> element. Usually rendered as a heading or label for the details element that users clicks to expand or collapse the details element
Superscript
Outermost element of svg documents but also for embedding svg content within html documents
Tabular data. Parent element for all table content
Table body. Encapsulates the main content of the table
Table cell
For defining a template for reuse
Multi-line plain-text editing control
Table footer
Header cell
Table header
Represents a specific period in time. Can be used to represent a date, a time, or a date and time
Document title. Text only. If there are html tags present in the title element, they are treated as text
Table row
Used as a child of the media elements (<video>, <audio>) to provide captions, subtitles, or other timed text tracks

Represents text that should be stylistically different from normal text, typically for non-textual annotations. Common uses include proper name marks in Chinese text, spelling errors. When possible, use CSS text-decoration for purely visual underlining
Unordered list of items. Typically rendered as bulleted list
Variable or placeholder text in a mathematical expression or computer program
Embeds video into document
Word break opportunity. Used to indicate where a line break is allowed but not required (in case that the rule of the parent element is not followed)
